title: Ticket #3698: Proper gsoap crashes
description:
Fedora/EPEL adds a patch to their gsoap for IPv6 support.

Unfortunately, this changes the layout of struct soap. By default, objects compiled against the EPEL /usr/include/stdsoap2.h result in code INCOMPATIBLE with /usr/lib64/libgsoapssl++.so. Things will link fine, but segfault at runtime.

One variant of this issue is when a Globus callout is made where the globus plugin uses gsoap - half the symbols are from condor and half from the gsoap library. So, the plugin, condor, and the gsoap library all need to be compiled with '-DWITH_IPV6'. This affects PROPER builds only; UW builds were fixed in #3625 (in UW builds, we statically link in libgsoapssl++ and hide symbols from IPv6). The fix for #3625 also broke compilation on SL6 for HTCondor 8.0.0 when PROPER and gsoap are enabled (symbol visibility issues).

To fix this, we need to compile anything that uses gsoap with '-DWITH_IPV6'. We should turn this on for PROPER builds but have the code continue to work even if the gsoap version used doesn't have the IPv6 patch.

2013-Jun-28 16:34:42 by adesmet:
Review notes (Finished 2013-Jul-08)

  1. condor_sockaddr::condor_sockaddr(const sockaddr_storage * sa) 's implementation doesn't work. It looks like the intent is to call another constructor. What it actually does is construct a temporary condor_sockaddr and immediately discard it; the immediate object remains uninitialized. The code in condor_sockaddr(const sockaddr * saddr); needs to be moved to a shared function and both functions should call it.

    • Actually it doesn't look like the new constructor is being used at all. But... likely to be useful in the future.

  2. RESOLVED: How safe is relying on sizeof(sockaddr_in) not matching sizeof(sockaddr_storage). Seems highly likely to work, but is it actually guaranteed? (Also, confirm that struct soap::peer is actually sockaddr_in)

  3. RESOLVED: In soap_core.cpp, why are we memcpying when simple assignment should work? Resolution: It doesn't work because we need to make the compiler happy, and it won't let us slip invalid code through just because it's on a code that that should never be run. Sadly, the preprocessor lacks knowledge of types and sizeof, so it can't help us. We could solve the problem with a compile time option, but that makes making a mistake easier. We could solve the problem with a mess of casting, but that's a mess of casting. Brian's solution appears to be the best one we're left with.
    • if (sizeof(cursoap->peer) == sizeof(sockaddr_storage))
      • then presumably cursoap->peer is sockaddr_storage, and a straight assignment should work.
    • else
      • then (hopefully? ASSERT(sizeof(cursoap->peer) == sizeof(sockaddr_in))?), cursoap->peer is sockaddr_in, and simple assignment should work.

  4. Why is to_storage monkeying around with copying? Can't we just return this->storage?

  5. Ideally add unit tests for the new condor_sockaddr constructor and condor_sockaddr::to_storage to /src//condor_unit_tests/OTEST_condor_sockaddr.cpp . I'm most worried about the new constructor, as it's unused.

  6. Match local style. /src/condor_daemon_core.V6/soap_core.cpp cuddles braces next to if/else. (True in condor_sockaddr.cpp as well, but the code in question is going to disappear per point 4.)

  7. Would the name daemon.proper.version be better than daemon.version.proper? ".version" is arguably the extension ("This is a version script, suitable for passing to ld --version-script"). Seems like it would more obviously connect it to the existing daemon.version.

  8. RESOLVED: I was unclear about the purpose of the custom linker script; bbockelm's explaination below satisfies me.

2013-Jun-28 18:45:37 by bbockelm:
Thoughts:

  • Bah. I always screw up constructors in C++. Will fix.
  • We are guaranteed that sizeof(sockaddr_in) != sizeof(sockaddr_storage) -- at least on platforms which have IPv6 support. The definition of sockaddr_storage is that it must be castable to sockaddr_in if it is an IPv4 address. "struct soap::peer" is of type sockaddr_storage if "-DWITH_IPV6" is handed to the compiler; otherwise, it is sockaddr_in. That headache is the whole reason for this patch...
  • Simple assignment doesn't work. See below. I guess I could reinterpret_cast and do some pointer manipulation if you'd prefer that over memcpy.
  • Didn't realize that condor_sockaddr is a union. I can switch to returning this->storage. 

/usr/include/sys/socket.h:359:8: note: candidate function (the implicit copy assignment operator) not viable: no known conversion from 'const sockaddr_in' to 'const sockaddr_storage' for 1st argument;

Anything else? If you can respond to points 2 and 3, I will commit fixes to 1 and 4.

2013-Jul-01 19:43:33 by bbockelm:
Alan asked via email about the motivation for the soap_* symbols to be publicly exported when doing a PROPER build as he thought libgsoap++ would provide them. For posterity, here was my response: 

Here's where things go awry.  libgsoap++ does *not* include these functions.
Rather, it expects these to be provided by executable linking against the library,
as it has missing references to these.

UW-build:

These symbols all remain hidden as libgsoap++ is statically linked against the
condor_* binary.  No gsoap-related symbols are publicly exported. Thus, any
plugin using gsoap can be loaded by condor without worrying about symbol leakage.

PROPER-build:

These symbols are public in order for the binary to be successfully linked against
libgsoap++.  Thus, any plugin using gsoap must use the exact same set of
defines as HTCondor and the system compilation of libgsoap++ in order to use
the same symbols (hence the addition of -DWITH_IPV6).

gsoap is a bad, bad library in that the structures align differently depending on
the defines - and the Fedora/EPEL packaging makes it so programs use the wrong
set of flags by default.  Doh!

(I feel like I've gotten a whole new level of linker education while working with gsoap...)

Hopefully someone finding this ticket via Google will find this enlightening.
